webTitle: Coca-Cola agrees to traffic-light labelling on drinks sold in UK

fields.standfirst: Brands such as Coke, Dr Pepper and Powerade will include labels showing recommended intakes of salt, sugar and fat
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has agreed to put traffic light-style labels on its drinks sold in the UK to help tackle the growing obesity crisis.

The move represents a major U-turn by the drinks giant, which makes brands such as Coke, Dr Pepper and Powerade, as it opposed last year's introduction of government-backed "hybrid" nutrition labels.

They use a combination of red, orange and green colours as well as information on recommended intakes of fat, salt and sugar to denote how healthy or unhealthy a product is.

"Our UK consumers have told us they want a single, consistent front-of-pack labelling scheme across all food and drink products to help them make the right choices for them and their families," said Jon Woods, the firm's general manager for the UK and Ireland. The new labels will appear on its products in the first half of next year.

Jane Ellison, the public health minister, praised Coca-Cola for adopting a scheme which, although backed by all the major supermarkets, is still being shunned by Kellogg's, Heinz, Unilever and others.

Richard Lloyd, executive director of the consumer group Which?, called on other major food and drink producers to follow Coca-Cola's lead and sign up.

webTitle: Hewlett-Packard concerns over Autonomy deals with Washington firm

fields.standfirst: Details of Autonomy's takeover of MicroLink revealed, as Hewlett-Packard's action continues over alleged 'improprieties'
fields.body:
Autonomy, the leading British technology firm whose former management is accused of inflating its value, sold $23m of software to a small Washington reseller in the year to December 2009. In February 2010, as some of the money began to fall due, Autonomy bought the company.

MicroLink was a security-cleared IT contractor working with US government departments, employing 140 people at offices in Virginia, on the outskirts of Washington DC. On 9 February 2010, with around $7m in payments overdue by more than a month, according to documents seen by the Guardian, Autonomy announced the acquisition of MicroLink for $55m.

Mike Lynch, the Cambridge scientist who founded Autonomy, his finance director Sushovan Hussain, and the group's auditor Deloitte have been threatened with legal action by Hewlett-Packard, which acquired Autonomy for $11bn in 2011. A year later, HP shocked investors by marking down the value of the British group by $5bn, blaming "accounting improprieties".

The transactions with MicroLink are understood to be among those questioned by HP. A spokeswoman for the Californian computing group said: "As HP has consistently stated, Autonomy senior management participated in deals with value-added resellers designed either to improperly accelerate revenue recognition or to manufacture revenue where none existed, all with the end goal of making Autonomy appear to be growing at a faster rate than was actually the case."

Autonomy's founder and former managers deny any wrongdoing, attributing much of the problem to differences between UK and US accounting standards, and blaming the write-down on mismanagement of Autonomy by HP.

A spokesman for the former managers dismissed as false any suggestions the purchase of MicroLink was designed to wipe out its debt to the British firm. In fact, they claim MicroLink helped secure $150m in US government sales over the following years.

The spokesman said: "Revenue is revenue if it translates into cash, and the cash is all there. HP's own accounts confirm it. As is normal for a business doing 15,000 transactions during that time, sometimes a customer didn't pay all their bills, but it didn't happen often, and it was covered by provisions in the accounts, meaning there was no impact on the accounts or the growth rate."

The Guardian has seen papers which show Deloitte was aware of the transactions and flagged them to Autonomy's audit committee. A spokesperson for the auditor said: "Deloitte conducted its audit work in full compliance with regulation and professional standards."

When MicroLink became part of Autonomy, nearly $12m of the software it had not yet paid for remained unsold. Following the takeover, $11.5m of the $23m debt was deemed not owing, in calculations approved by Deloitte. During 2010, the Guardian has seen evidence that Autonomy retrieved $7.7m in cash from MicroLink – less than half the original debt.

By the second quarter of 2010, $3.8m remained not accounted for. It was however covered by a provision of $5m in Autonomy's accounts. The provision, essentially a cushion against invoices that might not be collected, was approved by Deloitte. Former management say the sum was not material when compared to the British firm's $870m in revenues for 2010.

When announcing the purchase, Autonomy did not explain in its financial statements that it was buying a reseller which owed tens of millions of dollars. However, the sum owed appears to have been significant for both parties.

MicroLink's net annual revenues – the margin it made on top of the tens of millions of software it re-sold – in 2008 were $22m, and its projected revenues for 2009 were $25m, according to papers Lynch showed to his board before the purchase. So the $23m MicroLink owed Autonomy was the equivalent of a year's revenues. For Autonomy, the debt equalled 10% of all money outstanding from its various business partners as of December 2009. Microlink's previous owners, David Truitt and Timothy Wharton, declined to comment.

The price paid for the reseller was verified by Autonomy's auditors and subject to a fair value test by an independent consultancy. Of the $11.5m considered no longer owing, $6.9m was for Autonomy products which MicroLink had acquired to include in its own software, according to Autonomy's former management. Once the British firm owned MicroLink, that product was registered as an asset.

A further $4.6m was Autonomy software which MicroLink collected payment for, from its customers, but had not yet passed to the British company by the time of the takeover in February 2010.

The decision to buy MicroLink, taken in December 2009, was driven by Autonomy's concern that the US government was increasingly worried about dealing with a foreign owned company, albeit one based in Cambridge rather than Beijing. At the time, Autonomy's US business, which accounted for half of its global headcount, had sensitive contracts with the departments of defence and homeland security.

An internal email dated September 2009, seen by the Guardian, shows Lynch was advised that in order to continue working for federal agencies, the US division would need to be run at arm's length. UK managers would only be able visit or make phone calls by prior arrangement, and a separate management board would have to be installed.

Autonomy decided it would be more practical to purchase MicroLink, a company it had done business with since 2006 and which already had 86 security cleared staff.

"Autonomy acquired MicroLink so it could keep supplying software to sensitive branches of the US federal government," a spokesman for Autonomy's former managers said. "MicroLink's most important assets were its security cleared personnel and a secure facility. Without it, changes to the US government rules meant that, as a foreign owned company, Autonomy would have had to withdraw from this significant market."

Details of MicroLink's debt have emerged from a letter sent by Autonomy to the Financial Reporting Review Panel, which polices how listed companies communicate with their shareholders. The panel conducted a review of Autonomy in 2011 but took no further action. Following HP's allegations, the panel opened a full inquiry in 2013, which is ongoing. The Guardian has also seen Deloitte audit notes and emails.

webTitle: Superdry owner SuperGroup's shares up 14% after 'flying start' to season

fields.standfirst: Retailer says cold August boosted sales of jackets and hoodies as it prepares for launch of skiwear range in November
fields.body:
SuperGroup, the British company behind the Superdry fashion brand, has said its new season sales had got off to a flying start, with autumn jackets and hoodies selling well, aided by the disappointing August weather.

The company's shares closed up nearly 14% after the retailer also reported a better than expected first-quarter performance, with total retail sales in the three months to 26 July up 13.6% to £60.4m.

"There has been a material shift in performance in the latter five weeks as we have gone into autumn-winter ranges," said finance director Shaun Wills. "There's a consistency across our geographies and channels that suggests that the ranges are resonating with the customers quite well."

However, sales during the first quarter at stores open more than a year fell 3.7%. The company said this reflected strong sales in the same period last year, shortages of key spring-summer lines such as shorts and polo shirts and a highly competitive market, with rivals in the youth sector such as Ted Baker, Asos and Abercrombie & Fitch discounting more than in previous years.

The retailer also released a more up-to-date sales figure, which took in the last five weeks and which analysts said implied like-for-like sales growth was running at 6% in August.

Chief executive Julian Dunkerton said the new season was "all about jackets" and pointed to the launch of its first skiwear range in November. It has opened a store in the Alpine resort of Kitzbühel and Dunkerton said more would follow if the range was well received by skiers. He added that Superdry had a strong pipeline of new stores, especially in Germany, where six outlets, including the German flagship in Munich, are due to open before the end of the year.

Dunkerton said sales performance continued to be affected by issues including weak sales of its womenswear range. He admitted the chain had gone "a bit too fashion" with womenswear. In the new ranges, he said, instead of having three differently designed dresses, Superdry was backing winners and offering "our best dress in three different colours". "We are buying and selling with more confidence," he said.

Investec analyst Kate Calvert said the better-than-expected performance would reassure investors that Superdry's UK business was "solid" and that the retailer's long-term growth remained intact. "As the new season ranges came in, the industry generally benefited from the colder snap and competitive pressures eased."

Analysts predict SuperGroup will make pre-tax profits of £70.3m in the current financial year, up from last year's £62m.

Before the trading update the shares had lost more than a quarter of their value this year with investors bailing out after reports of weak sales in the previous period. They surged yesterday to close 145p up at 1191p.

webTitle: Go-Ahead enjoys leaping profits as it takes over rail franchise

fields.standfirst: Go-Ahead is set to start operating the Thameslink, Southern and Great Northern commuter franchise from 14 September
fields.body:
Bus and rail operator Go-Ahead has announced leaping profits and record passenger numbers, as it gets ready to take over Britain's biggest rail franchise.

Chief executive, David Brown, said it had been a "busy and exciting year" as operating profits topped £100m, mainly driven by margins of 10% on its London and regional bus services.

In its Govia joint venture with SNCF subsidiary Keolis, Go-Ahead is set to start operating the Thameslink, Southern and Great Northern commuter franchise from 14 September, the annual revenues from which will top £1bn.

Brown said: "We will be the largest train operator in the UK once we take over." But he said current profit margins were only 1% in the rail business, due to the lifespan of the contracts with the government.

Govia is also shortlisted for the Northern and TransPennine Express rail franchises.

He added that Go-Ahead "continued to make a positive contribution to society through the services we run, careful environmental stewardship and the taxes we pay." The company was the first in the FTSE 350 to be awarded the Fair Tax Mark, in a scheme aiming to hold firms to account. Brown stressed he hoped to be "the first, not the only". The group paid £12.4m in corporation tax, on profits before tax of £91.2m, up 44% from 2013.

The firm could also claimed innovation in smart ticketing and fuel saving, Brown said. Its Key smartcard now enables bus customers to book other services throughout the country – for example Brighton bus passengers can travel on Southern trains to London and use public transport on the same card. Meanwhile the flywheel Formula One technology that stores energy through braking is due to be fitted to 500 of its buses, reducing fuel consumption and emissions.

webTitle: Richard Pennycook was the best, or perhaps only, man for top Co-op job

fields.standfirst: Interim CEO has taken job permanently despite insisting he did not want it. It's easy to see why he had few rivals for the role
fields.body:
After Euan Sutherland's spectacular departure from the Co-operative Group six months ago (he called the company ungovernable), headhunters were always going to struggle to produce a queue of big-hitters wanting the job of chief executive.

Governance reform is on the way at the Co-op but that does not mean every ambitious boss in retail land wants to work there.

In the event, the soon-to-depart chair Ursula Lidbetter has saved recruiters the bother. The group has appointed Richard Pennycook, who has been filling the post since Sutherland's exit, on a permanent basis.

Hold on, though, didn't Pennycook say on several occasions that he wasn't seeking the post permanently? Yes, he did, and he sounded sincere. Sceptics will suspect the Co-op couldn't attract a big name. Generous souls will say Pennycook has done a decent job as a stand-in and deserves his chance.

The view here: Pennycook is a long way from being a flamboyant, or visionary boss, but so what? He's a details man, as he proved in a successful spell as finance director of Morrisons when he helped sort out the chaos of the Safeway acquisition. An undemonstrative nuts-and-bolts operator may be exactly what the Co-op needs.

Its main retail division is seeking to prosper as a convenience-store specialist, which is not going to be easy as the big supermarket chains try to expand on the same patch. Pennycook seems a reasonable pick. What he needs, though, is some top-quality non-executive directors from outside the group, especially an experienced chairman. That's what the Co-op promises to deliver – get on with it.

webTitle: Investors fire warning shot at Betfair executive bonuses

fields.bodyText: Nearly a third of shareholders in online betting exchange Betfair on Thursday voted against pay and bonus arrangements for the company's directors. Corporate governance group ISS had recommended investors vote against Betfair's boardroom pay deals, arguing the performance requirement for one long-term, share-based bonus had been made easier "contrary to standard market practice". Some 24m shares, 32% of votes cast, were against Betfair's remuneration report, with a further 2.2m abstention votes underlining the unpopularity of the group's executive pay deals. Last year, only 4.6% or shareholders voted against the pay report. A spokesman for Betfair said: "The board understands that it is the policy of certain shareholders to oppose any amendments to targets and discussions with those shareholders voting against this resolution highlighted the change to the 2011 [long-term award] as the cause of opposition. The current management does not participate in this scheme and the remuneration of current management was not raised in any of these shareholder discussions." Before the meeting, however, there had also been separate criticsm from another corporate governance group Pirc, which had taken issue with pay arrangements for chief executive Breon Corcoran, suggesting he could be entitled to a bonus of up to 380% of his salary. It described performance benchmarks as "not adequate" and suggested share rewards were released too quickly. Corcoran's pay package was worth £1.28m for 2014, according to the annual report, down from £3.7m the previous year, when he joined the business. His 2013 remuneration was boosted by a "golden hello" of restricted share awards and payments to cover his relocation from Ireland. A Pirc report, issued earlier this week, told investors: "Awarded [Betfair] CEO pay is not considered in line with the company's financial performance over the last five years." Pirc had recommended a binding vote against Betfair's boardroom pay policy, but investors instead chose to target the resolution on the company's remuneration report – a milder protest as the result is not binding on the board. There was only a small ripple of protest from shareholders in relation to Betfair's annual report, with 6% of votes case either against or in abstention to the resolution. A usually uncontentious matter, this vote to receive the financial statements of directors and auditors KPMG attracted controversy after Betfair was forced to concede in its 2014 annual report that it had technically breached certain rules relating to dividends and share buybacks in past years. • This article was amended on 8 September 2014 to clarify the results of the vote on boardroom pay and add a response from Betfair.

12.06pm BST

12.05pm BST

Any excuse to mention Clement Attlee:

12.01pm BST

Bank of England leaves interest rates and QE unchanged

To no-one’s surprise, the Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 0.5%, and also maintained its QE programme at £375bn.

We now have to wait two weeks for the minutes of today’s meeting, to find how many MPC members wanted a rate rise (it split 7-2 last month).

11.58am BST

Reports: ECB considering €500bn ABS/covered bond programme

Reuters has just reported that the European Central Bank’s governing council is considering throwing up to €500bn behind an asset-backed securities programme.

It could be announced today, unless there is opposition from members of the council. The ECB has declined to comment.

Here’s Reuters’ first take:

Plans to launch an asset-backed securities (ABS) and covered bond purchase programme worth up to 500 billion euros are on the table at Thursday’s European Central Bank policy meeting, people familiar with the discussions say.

ECB President Mario Draghi will likely announce such a programme at his news conference unless it comes up against strong opposition at the Governing Council’s policy meeting.

The programme would have a duration of three years and comprise both ABS and covered bond purchases. The ECB could begin buying the assets this year, the people familiar with the discussions told Reuters.The ECB declined to comment.

It’s not a shock that the ECB is considering an ABS programme, of course.

But the size of the programme is new. And if it doesn’t happen now, we’ll know that there are divisions over the plan.

Also, it’s pretty rare to get a central bank leak during the meeting...

11.51am BST

In the UK, car sales have risen for the 30th month running, a record, as consumers continue to splash out on new models.

A sign that consumer confidence remains solid, and is underpinning the recovery (there’ s also speculation that PPI mis-selling payouts has been pushing demand)

More here: UK drivers splash out on new cars as record run of sales continues

11.47am BST

11.41am BST

Very droll, sir....

For new readers, ABS = asset backed securities. Mario Draghi may pre-announce details of an ABS programme to encourage banks to package together, or securitise, loans into a new debt instrument to sell to the ECB.

Securitisation, of course, was one cause of the 2008 financial crisis, after banks bundling some pretty dubious home loans together and selling them on.

11.14am BST

Jeroen Dijsselbloem went on to tell MEPs that he doesn’t believe the eurozone will slip into deflation, despite the CPI measure of inflation hitting a five-year low of just 0.3%.

He said:

“I don’t actually see deflationary risks , but I see a risk of a long term of a very low inflation which has to be broken through.”

10.54am BST

Eurogroup chief issues warning over eurozone recovery

The eurozone recovery is very uneven and fragile, but the European Central Bank should resist launching new measures today.

That’s the message from the head of the eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers, Jeroen Dijsselbloem.

Testifying in Brussels this morning, Dijsselbloem said that governments must implement structural reforms, rather than simply rely on easy monetary policy.

He also argued that the European Central Bank shouldn’t launch a quantitative easing programme now, as we don’t know whether its existing measures will work.

Dijsselbloem, who is also the Dutch finance minister, told the European Parliament’s economic and monetary committee that:

Recent economic data confirm that the recovery in the euro zone remains very fragile and uneven.

I believe that recent developments underscore the need to push forwards the growth and reform agenda. Fundamental challenges faced by the euro zone are unchanged,

Dijsselbloem’s appearance comes as the ECB governing council ponders whether to make new measures to help the eurozone (see opening post).

The eurogroup head reckons we won’t know until early 2015 whether ECB measures announced three months ago - such as the TLTRO offer of cheap loans to banks - are working.

He says:

“The June package has not been given enough consideration in our analysis and the results of that June package through the TLTRO has yet to actually take place,” .

“Whether the ECB needs to do more will be up to their [the ECB’s] judgment in the next few months, but I think we also have to realize in June a number of additional measures were taken by the ECB and their effect doesn’t materialize within a day or a week. It takes time.”

10.51am BST

And this handy chart shows how the ECB’s June inflation forecasts failed to predict the recent slide in annual price growth, to just 0.3% last month.

10.37am BST

10.17am BST

10.02am BST

Spanish borrowing costs hit record low

Spanish borrowing costs have hit new all-time lows at a debt auction this morning, as anticipation of an ECB QE programme drives demand for sovereign debt.

Spain had no trouble raising €3bn, with investors accepting lower rates of return than ever before.

It sold €2.3bn of 10-year bonds at average yields of just 2.27%, down from 2.68% last time.

And the yield on €700m of 30-year bonds fell to 3.59%, from 4.03%. That highlights the low inflation expectations for the euro area, as well as the prospect of the ECB easing policy further...

9.40am BST

As well as celebrating his promotion, Richard Pennycook can also be cheered that Co-op is back in the black.

It made a pre-tax profit of £19m, not immense, but a damn sight better than the £843m loss a year ago after its banking problems came to light.

The supermarkets and funerals business generated most of the profits:

9.23am BST

The Co-op has also reported that underlying profits have slumped by 43% in the first half of the year, to just £66m, as the crisis at its Bank arm rocked the group.

9.22am BST

Richard Pennycook named as Co-op Group CEO

Just in. Britain’s Co-operative Group has just announced that it has appointed a new CEO to steer the organisation out of its current troubles.

They’ve named Richard Pennycook, who’s actually been working as interim CEO since March. He joined the Group as finance director in July 2013, so he’s not a complete break from the past.

Ursula Lidbetter, Chair, insists he’s the right man - just days after members agreed a major shake-up of how the Co-op runs.

Lidbetter said:

“The Co-operative Group needs strong, talented, committed leadership as it starts on the next phase of its recovery and I am delighted that Richard has accepted the role of Group Chief Executive. Last week we secured the overwhelming approval of our members for far-reaching governance reform.

We are now moving forward with the work to bring to life the new structure.

Pennycook warns that “we have much to do to return the Group to full financial health and improve the performance of our businesses,” but adds that Co-op still has a “bright and exciting” time ahead.

He was made interim CEO in March after Euan Sutherland dramatically quit, saying the group was ungovernable...

9.05am BST

Allianz: Don't do it, Mario

It could be disastrous if the European Central Bank launched a quantitative easing programme, says Michael Heise, chief economist of German insurance group Allianz.

Writing in the FT, Heise warns that QE would expose taxpapers to risks*, and wouldn’t encourage borrowing as many households are already heavily indebted. More cheap money would also deter banks from fixing their balance sheets, he argues.

* - which looks unlikely, given the recovery in sovereign bond prices over the last two years

Heise also points out that the weak inflation is partly due to lower energy prices - QE won’t solve that.

Here’s his conclusion:

Monetary policy alone cannot and will not return the eurozone to sustainable growth, as Mario Draghi, the ECB president, pointed out at the Jackson Hole gathering of central bankers last month.

Improvements in labour markets and the investment climate, sustainable fiscal reforms and a shift of public spending towards growth-boosting investments in infrastructure and education are what Europe must focus on now.

Quantitative easing would sow the seeds of crisis not recovery

Updated at 11.32am BST

8.55am BST

Aurelija Augulyte of Nordea Markets flags up that market expectations for inflation have risen a little since Mario Draghi pledged to use “all available” powers to ward off deflation.

This graph shows that investors still expect eurozone prices to lag those in the US and UK, but aren’t quite as worried about deflation.

This is the key measure which the ECB will use when assessing whether to do QE.

More in her blog: Draghi’s breakfast

8.50am BST

Standard Life shares surge 10% after Canadian deal

In the City, shares in Standard Life have soared by over 10% after it surprised the City by agreeing to sell its 180-year-old Canadian business for £2.2bn in cash.

Most of the money (£1.75bn) will be handed back to shareholders, and the clamour has driven Standard Life’s shares to the top of the FTSE 100 leaderboard, up by 39p to 425p.

Otherwise, as predicted, it’s quiet. The FTSE 100 is up 6 points at 6880.

8.35am BST

Analysts at UBS also reckon Mario Draghi will leave quantitative easing in his toolbox today

8.32am BST

Credit Agricole: Draghi may hint at QE down the line

Mario Draghi may drop hints about a potential QE programme in future today, reckons Credit Agricole’s ECB expert, Frederik Ducrozet.

He predicts that the ECB could trim the cost of taking part in its new offer of cheap long-term loans to eurozone banks (called TLTRO), and also pre-announce a plan to buy securitised debs from the banks.

He also reckons the ECB may stick to its forecast that inflation moves back towards target by 2016, even if it is forced to downgrade its 2014 and 2015 forecasts

8.22am BST

German factory orders jump, in 'encouraging sign'

Here’s a surprise. German factory orders have jumped to their highest level in over a year, suggesting Europe’s largest economy may be recovering from its weakness earlier this year.

Industrial orders bounced by 4.6% in July, compared to June, smashing expectations of a 1.5% rise. It was driven by strong demand from outside the euro area, particularly for capital goods (heavy machinery).

Some highlights:

  • Domestic orders: +1.7% month-on-month
  • Foreign orders: +6.9%.
  • eurozone orders - +1.7%
  • non-eurozone: +9.8%

Germany’s finance ministry is upbeat, saying:

After the uncertainty caused by geopolitical developments and a weaker economy in the second quarter, the strong rise in orders is an encouraging signal for the industrial economy.”

We need to be cautious; orders over the May-July period are still lower than in the previous three months.

7.49am BST

ECB decision and press conference dominates the day

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the economy, the eurozone and business.

With growth stalling, prices heading towards deflation, and geopolitical risks on the rise, this is a tricky time to be a central banker. And today, Mario Draghi and the rest of the European Central Bank’s governing council must decide whether to take fresh action to aid the eurozone.

They’re meeting in Frankfurt this morning to set monetary policy across the region. We get their decision at 12.45pm BST, followed by the big event of the day (if not the week), Draghi’s press conference at 1.30pm BST.

It’s the first ECB meeting since Draghi dramatically pledged to use “all available instruments needed to ensure price stability”.

The latest slump in inflation, to just 0.3% in August, means this could be the day when the ECB takes the historic decision to launch a huge quantitative easing programme (buying government bonds on a major scale). But it almost certainly won’t be.

QE may be coming soon, but it’s more likely that today Draghi will talk up another weapon in the ECB’s armoury. Many economists believe he’ll pre-announce a plan to buy asset-backed securities (ABSs) from eurozone banks. An ABS programme could encourage banks to agree loans with businesses, so the debt can be packaged up into a new security and sold to the ECB.

That might help. But Julian Jessop of Capital Economics reckons the ECB must launch QE eventually...

It has also been our long-held view that the ECB will eventually be forced to adopt full-blown quantitative easing (QE), involving large-scale outright purchases of government bonds.

And the latest activity and price data, including evidence on inflation expectations, have surely brought the timing of that announcement forward.

With interest rates so low, a further cut in borrowing costs is unlikely, but not impossible.

The ECB will also update its economic forecasts; its staff are likely to have taken the red pen to June’s projections, given the weak inflation and GDP figures since.

It’s also Bank of England decision day. We’re not expecting a change in interest rates, even though the monetary policy committee split 7-2 last month.

But with the services sector growing strongly last month, and construction firms struggling to find skilled staff, there’s lots for the BoE to ponder. Their decision comes at noon BST.

The stock markets look calm this morning, after the FTSE 100 hit a new 14 year high yesterday.

Also coming up....

9am: The UK car registrations figures, for August.

1.15pm BST: The monthly measure of US private sector employment, which will give clues to tomorrow’s non-farm payroll.

Updated at 8.06am BST
fields.bodyText: OK, that’s all for today. We’ll have an updated news story on today’s developments online shortly. The post-press conference summary (at 3.12 pm) explains the main measures announced by the European Central Bank; interest rate cuts to fresh record lows, and a new programme to stimulate the eurozone economy by buying bundles of debt (including loans to firms, and home mortgages). The International Monetary Fund has backed the plan, with Christine Lagarde saying: “We strongly welcome the measures taken by the ECB, which will help to counteract the dangers posed by an extended period of low inflation.” Perhaps a touch of ‘I told you so’, given the IMF has repeatedly called for more action from the ECB? European stock markets have hit their highest levels since January 2008, as investors welcome the latest easing of monetary policy. And the euro has weakened dramatically against the US dollar, down over two cents at one stage to $1.2935. Many analysts have predicted that today’s moves mean the ECB is now unlikely to launch quantitative easing soon. Brenda Kelly of IG explains: “The governing council agreed to use all unconventional measures at its disposal to hit its mandate – stable inflation at 2%. While this might suggest that a quantitative easing programme is still possible, the decline in the euro and the diverging policies of western central banks would indicate extraordinary stimulus of this nature will be kicked into the long grass for now.” Rolling reaction starts here. And the Institute of Directors has echoed Mario Draghi’s call for more structural reform in the euro area, saying: “The Eurozone economies face a number of significant challenges, from insufficient flexibility in their labour markets to heavy-handed regulations stifling entrepreneurialism. Long-term liberalisation is the key to putting the Eurozone back on the path to stability and growth, not short term monetary policy tools.” Back tomorrow, when we get the latest US jobs data (yup, it’s Non-Farm Payroll Friday). Goodnight, and thanks. GW Frederik Ducrozet of Crédit Agricole’s analyst note on the ECB is well worth a read; it includes this handy summary of the key points: The ECB unexpectedly cut all policy rates today, bringing the Refi rate down to 0.05% and the deposit rate to -0.20%. The TLTROs will therefore be conducted at 0.15%. This time the ECB reached the lower bound as Draghi promised there would be no more rate cuts. The other announcements (an ABS and Covered Bonds purchases programme, with operational details coming in October) and changes to the official statement and staff forecasts were broadly in line with our expectations. Crucially, Draghi explicitly hinted at an increase in the ECB’s balance sheet of roughly €1,000bn to bring it back to the 2012 highs (€3,100bn). The idea would be to get there using both net liquidity injections from TLTROs and outright asset purchases (circa €500bn each), although it could take longer than expected. We see the latest easing measures as very positive for the medium- term macro outlook, hence we continue to rule out sovereign QE. Still, the burden of proof will remain on upcoming macro and inflation data. Christian Schulz, senior economist at Berenberg bank, is concerned that the ECB didn’t give more detail about its plans for an asset-backed securities programme. That suggest serious dissent among the governing council, he says: The ECB has stepped up to the plate, again, as the Eurozone recovery almost grinds to a halt. The confidence shock of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine and reform delays in France and Italy are threatening the projected gradual rebound of inflation towards target. After easing policy significantly – and with quantifiable effect – in June, the ECB today announced more measures. But, amid apparent serious disagreements, the ECB was unable to provide details of the scale of its asset purchase programmes, and may have added modest rate cuts to underline its intent to do more to support the recovery If you’re just joining us (where were you?!), I’ve been mopping up reaction to today’s surprising moves from the European Central Bank, from 3.33pm. Here’s some more, from Eimear Daly, Head of Market Analysis at Monex Europe. She sums up today’s news, and also predicts that QE is now on the back-burner for a while at least. Draghi shy to implement QE emergency kit “ECB’s Draghi certainly wasn’t bluffing at his surprise appearance at Jackson Hole. The de-anchoring of inflation expectations obviously gravely unsettled the central banker and with it came Draghi’s ay caramba moment, a realisation that growth is actually needed to generate inflation. In his late August speech, Draghi set out his new pro-growth doctrine and while he maintains his iron-cast belief that structural reforms must be taken to shake-up Europe’s rigid and over-encumbered economies, he recognised that fiscal and monetary policy equally have their part to play. At today’s press conference, Draghi put his thesis into action, announcing an across the board cut to interest rates and an Asset-Backed Securities programme to give demand a much needed push.” The 10 basis points that were shaved off all headline rates were purely symbolic. The cut highlights the point that the ECB is in an easing cycle, while the rest of the developed economies ready themselves for higher rates. The cut did its job, sending the euro sharply lower and thus instantly addressing a source of the Eurozone’s deflationary pressure.” Draghi’s announcement of new asset-backed securities purchase programmes, aiming to finally get credit to the Eurozone starved corporates, meant he has recognised that the Eurozone’s zombie banking sector is failing to support economic growth. In effect, the ECB is now going over the banking sector’s heads. While no face value of purchases was given, this factor is almost immaterial. The fact that the world’s second biggest central bank is now actively investing in this market will drive global investors into these assets and the ECB’s seal of approval is worth more than any target amount of purchases.” ECB QE is the last remaining tool in the bank’s arsenal and Draghi admitted that some members wanted to do more than today’s measures. After surviving a sovereign debt crisis and a severe recession, Draghi does not want to cave in to doing QE now and it will remain locked in the bank’s emergency kit while their other measures attempt to resuscitate Eurozone inflation. In effect, these measures may be more effective than buying government debt ever would be and thus the QE kit will continue to gather dust.” The euro has continued to lose value against the US dollar as traders take stock of the ECB’s decisions. It’s now down more than two cents, or 1.6%, at $1.2935. That’s a new 14-month low, and I imagine Mario Draghi will be rather pleased to see it. A weaker euro will help push up inflation, and give manufacturers a boost. As this chart shows, the euro tumbled after the ECB cut interest rates at 12.45pm BST, and then continued to weaken as the asset-backed securities plan was announced. European stock markets have just closed at their highest level since the early days of the financial crisis. The FTSEurofirst 300 index, which tracks the biggest companies across the region, has risen by 1.2% today to its highest close since January 2008. That was the month before Northern Rock was nationalised, and eight months before Lehman Brothers failed. Italy’s FTSE MIB surged by 2.9%, followed by Spain’s IBEX (+2%) as investors hailed the interest rate cuts, and new asset-backed securities programme, announced by the ECB today (if you missed it, there’s a summary here). Tony Cross, market analyst at Trustnet Direct, says: The reaction in equity markets goes to show just how worryingly tethered investors remain to loose monetary policy. The FTSE 100 was dragged back by BP, which shed almost 6% in its biggest one-day fall in four years after a US court ruled it was grossly negligent over the 2010 Gulf of Mexico disaster. Mario Draghi has received a strong vote of support from Christine Lagarde, managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). In a statement, Lagarde made it clear that she backs today’s decisions, saying: “We strongly welcome the measures taken by the ECB, which will help to counteract the dangers posed by an extended period of low inflation.” The IMF has been pushing the ECB for month to do more to help the eurozone economy; in June, it recommended considering a broad-based asset purchase scheme. Marc Ostwald of ADM Investor Services says that the European Central Bank is clearly focusing on (the lack of) growth, rather than simply price stability. He writes: The key point is that the ECB is in effect implementing policy on the basis of the GDP and Unemployment outlook - not inflation. Some may well observe that this is not ‘not before time’, and they are still well behind the curve. In effect the ECB’s implicit policy parameters are much the same as the Fed and the BoE, even if like the BoE it will attempt to frame the rationale for policy moves in terms of its inflation target. Analysts at ABN Amro reckon today’s measures will have “positive effects” on the eurozone economic outlook. The package will likely put some further downward pressure on the euro, which will give an impulse to economic growth and inflation. In addition, they will help to improve bank lending. The TLRTOs, and the ABS and covered bond programmes will provide banks with lower cost funding. The ABS purchase programme could also help revive that market, which will also allow banks to remove some assets from their balance sheets. Furthermore, these measures are part of a more comprehensive package of measures. The AQR and stress tests should increase the transparency of bank balance sheets and lead to re-capitalisation where necessary. Given that our central scenario is broadly in line with the ECB’s, we do not expect additional measures over and above the ones announced today. That didn’t take long -- the newswires have established that Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann opposed today’s ECB decisions. The Institute of Directors, which represents Britain’s top bosses, wants eurozone leaders to heed Mario Draghi’s call for structural reforms. Chief economist James Sproule says: What’s really needed here is action by individual governments rather than abdicating responsibility for domestic woes to the ECB. “The Eurozone economies face a number of significant challenges, from insufficient flexibility in their labour markets to heavy-handed regulations stifling entrepreneurialism. Long-term liberalisation is the key to putting the Eurozone back on the path to stability and growth, not short term monetary policy tools.” The ECB has finally “sat up and paid attention” to the sluggish eurozone recovery and the rising disinflationary pressures, says Brenda Kelly of IG: She adds that QE may be off the table for a while: “The ECB has essentially manifested its commitment to its goals when it drove the overnight deposit rate deeper into negative territory, now charging banks 0.2% to leave funds with it - and cut its marginal lending facility - or emergency borrowing rate - to 0.3%. “The governing council agreed to use all unconventional measures at its disposal to hit its mandate – stable inflation at 2%. While this might suggest that a quantitative easing programme is still possible, the decline in the euro and the diverging policies of western central banks would indicate extraordinary stimulus of this nature will be kicked into the long grass for now. Back to today’s European Central Bank decisions. Aberdeen Asset Management Investment Manager Luke Bartholomew comments: “For years the ECB has been very slow to react and often frustrated markets. But in the face of dire and clearly worsening economic indicators Draghi has actually gone beyond markets’ expectations today. The frustration is that it has taken so long with inflation having already fallen so low, but it is certainly progress. Despite the fact that today’s announcement was not unanimous, resistance to Draghi within the council is clearly receding as the European recovery wilts. “Purchasing asset backed securities and covered bonds could have a significant effect but no one really knows if there’s enough of these assets to buy in order to have the desired effect. The measures are effectively QE-lite and Draghi’s left the door open for more measures in the future. His promise that today’s cut in the deposit rates is the last is rather undermined by the fact that he made this same promise after the last cut, but he has to say this to encourage banks to take up his long term refinancing programme. Of course what he would really like is a much weaker euro, but the gentlemanly code of central banking means he can’t come out and say this explicitly.” Breaking away from the ECB briefly.... shares in BP have slid by almost 5% after a US court ruled that the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster was due to the oil giant’s “gross negligence and wilful misconduct”. Judge Barbier has assigned two-thirds responsibility for the oil spill to BP, which operated the oil rig which caught fire and sank four years ago. Transocean, which owned the rig, was 30% to blame, with US contractor Halliburton, who handled the cementing of the rig, just 3% responsible, Barbier concluded. One of the brightest analysts on the eurozone economy and the ECB, Lorcan Roche Kelly of Agenda Research, is encouraged by the splits that opened up at the governing council today: I’m going to wrap up the best reaction to today’s European Central Bank news now. First up, Gary Jenkins of LNG Capital, who reckons the chances of a quantitative easing programme have diminished: Mr Draghi was aggressively dovish early on, saying that the ‘Governing Council is unanimous in its commitment to using additional unconventional instruments..’ In other words, we have QE and we are prepared to use it. But later on Mr Draghi admitted that today’s decisions were not unanimous. The market may take the latter comment and decide that if Mr Draghi cannot get agreement on a very well flagged ABS program, will he be able to deliver on QE? Mario Draghi rarely disappoints, and today’s press conference is another reminder that the eurozone, for all its problems, does have a top-class central banker at the helm. Full highlights start here. But for new readers, here’s a quick reminder of the key points: 1) The European Central Bank has cut interest rates to fresh record lows in an attempt to stimulate inflation, and announced a new credit scheme to encourage lending and pump money into the eurozone banking sector. Mario Draghi announced that the governing council will launch an ‘asset-backed securities’ programme, buying up financial assets from banks and other investors. The ABS scheme will allow banks to sell bundles of assets, such as loans to companies and mortgages, to the ECB. Full details aren’t available, but it is likely to see the ECB commit hundreds of billions of euros. It’s not a full-blown quantitative easing programme, but it’s another step along the road. The idea is that banks will be more willing to make loans to the real economy if they can then package the debt into new securities and sell them to the ECB. 2) Borrowing costs are at new record lows, and Draghi admitted that the ECB is now at the ‘lower bound’ of interest rates. Today’s interest rate cute mean that the main refinancing rate is now just 0.05%, from 0.15%. The ECB also pushed the financial sector deeper into negative territory. It will now charge banks 0.2% to deposit cash overnight. 3) Today’s decisions were not unanimous. Draghi admitted that some members of the governing council wanted to do more today, while others favoured less. There was a “comfortable majority” in favour of today’s decisions, he said. But that lack of unanimity hints at a full-blooded exchange of views in Frankfurt today. 4) The ECB has cut its forecasts, conceding that the economy is weaker than expected three months ago. It now expects inflation of just 0.6%, from 0.7% in June. And it also sees GDP of just 0.9%, down from 1.0% before. 5) The ECB still wants eurozone governments to reform. During his statement, Draghi pointed out bluntly that while some governments have made significant structural progress, others have not yet legislated or implemented such work. He didn’t name names, but I’d put Spain in the former category, and both France and Italy in the latter. Draghi said that reforms: ..now clearly need to gain momentum to achieve higher sustainable growth and employment in the euro area. Determined structural reforms in product and labour markets as well as action to improve the business environment are warranted. And he also repeated several times that there was no secret pact that the ECB would ease policy in return for action by euro governments. We must all do our own jobs, he said. 6) The financial markets have welcomed today’s news. Stock markets hit their highest levels in six and a half-years. The euro has tumbled, shedding 1.5 cents against the US dollar to €1.3005 as the ‘arsenal of measures’ were digested. It’s the final question of a lively, and frankly complicated press conference -- is the ECB worried that inflation expectations are ‘decoupling’? Ie, losing faith in the ECB’s ability to get inflation close to 2%, from 0.3%, in the medium term. Mario Draghi winds up by insisting that the ECB does not expect full-blown deflation. There would be no value in misleading people, he insists. He concedes that forecasting errors have been made --mainly on food and energy prices, but recently on other factors, the amount of slack in the economy, and the (stubbornly high) unemployment rate. And the ECB chief points out that some of those changes are outside the central bank’s role. End of press conference. Summary and reaction to follow.... Mario Draghi has repeated that there is no hidden deal between eurozone governments and the ECB. Reminder - full coverage of the ECB press conference starts here. And details of today’s eurozone interest rate cuts are here. How can you say that the governing council is ‘unanimous’ in its determination to use all measures, and then be split over today’s decisions? Unanimity is not a blank cheque. We are united in our resolve, but there could be differences of views when the time comes to decide what measures to undertake, Draghi replies. Are inflation expectations still anchored? Yes, but the downside risk has increased, thus today’s measures. Draghi declined to say what he discussed with Italian prime minister Matteo Renzi. The discussion remains private. And he also explains that eurozone members should share fiscal responsibilities, rather than surrender them, just as they have with monetary policy. A question from the eurozone’s next member, Lithuania. How will the Lithuanian inflation rate differ from the eurozone average in the months ahead? Draghi elegantly avoids giving an answer, but pays tribute to the remarkable progress achieved by Lithuania in qualifying to join the euro. Something I missed earlier, is that Draghi has flagged up the idea of expanding the ECB’s balance sheet back to its 2012 levels. That balance sheet has been shrinking over the last two years, by around €1 trillion. The TLTRO loan programme could be up to €700bn, suggesting that the ABS programme agreed today will be at least €300bn (and could hit €500bn if the TLTRO total is lower). There’s no grand bargain in the eurozone between politicians and central bankers, Draghi insists. We just need to all keep doing our own jobs. Draghi harks back to his speech at Jackson Hole (the gathering of top US central bankers) last month. He explains that it is crucial to keep reforming the eurozone to make it more competitive -- from a confidence point of view it would be better to have very serious discussion about structural reforms first, before asking whether euro governments should be granted more flexibility. University of Bristol economist Tony Yates reckons the ABS could actually be more powerful than a quantitative easing programme. The new ABS programme we agreed today will buy up loans made to the real economy, Draghi explains. That includes residential mortgage-backed securities (ie, home loans packed together into a new financial instrument) Today’s measures will strengthen the TLTRO programme we announced in June, Draghi says. (TLTRO is the offer of cheap long-term loans to ECB banks). Banks now know that there is no point holding back from signing up to the TLTRO in case interest rates are cut in future, as they simply can’t be cut again. Mario Draghi explains that the ECB acted after seeing inflation expectations worsen in August. Draghi added that there’s nothing untoward about the appointment of US financial firm Blackrock to help with an asset-backed securities programme. The euro has fallen further, after Mario Draghi announced that the ECB will begin an asset-backed securities programme (basically, buying bundles of loans from the banks, in an attempt to get them to do more lending). It is hovering around $1.301, a drop of 1% or almost 1.5 cents. Mario Draghi starts explains that the governing council agreed to cut its three main interest rates at today’s meeting (as announced earlier). He says that the ECB governing council has also agreed to start buying non-financial assets through an asset-backed security programme. It will also include the purchase of covered bonds, as Reuters reported earlier today. We’ll get the details of this plan next month, after the October meeting. The plan will add to the range of monetary policy measures taken in recent months, Draghi says. And it will support our forward guidance on interest rates. It will also address the fact that the major world economies are at different stages of the economic cycle, he adds. Mario Draghi’s press conference will be streamed live here (right-click to open in a new browser tab). I’ll cover the key points and instant reaction here. If you’re just joining us, here’s a quick catch-up, before the ECB press conference: The European Central Bank has just cut interest rates to fresh record lows, and hit banks with deeper negative interests, at its monthly meeting. In a surprise move, the ECB’s governing council cut borrowing costs in the single currency area, in response to the latest weak inflation and low growth. The headline rate is now just 0.05%, from 0.15%. And banks will be charged 0.2% to leave money at the ECB rather than lending it to consumers and businesses. Analysts say the cut shows the depth of the ECB’s concern about deflation, and the recent poor economic data. The news sent the euro sliding to its lowest level in over a year, down almost 1% to $1.3031. There are also rumours that the ECB considered a new €500bn programme to stimulate bank lending -- nothing official yet, but Mario Draghi could drop hints (or more) in a few minutes.... Just 15 minute until the European Central Bank holds its press conference to explain today’s decisions. The big, big question is whether Mario Draghi announces new non-conventional measures in the press conference, or even hints at them.... The interest rate cuts show just how worried the ECB is about “very low and still falling Eurozone consumer price inflation, weakening inflation expectations and faltering Eurozone economic activity”, says Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight. Carsten Brzeski of ING suggests Mario Draghi may, finally, be preparing to flood the eurozone with cheap cash: Was this the start of Draghi’s helicopter? The ECB just announced a rate cut by 10bp, lowering the refi rate to 0.05%, from 0.15%. Both the marginal lending rate and the deposit rate were also cut by 10bp. At 2.30 pm CET, we will know whether this was the prelude to another monetary policy fireworks or just the easiest way out to prevent QE without a loss of face. European stock markets have rallied after the ECB cut interest rates. France’s CAC index surged 1%, on optimism that the move could help Europe out of its malaise. The Italian FTSE MIB is up by 1.5%. Today’s interest rate cut is a smart move by the European Central Bank, says our economics editor Larry Elliott. He explains that the ECB wants to drive the euro down, and has timed the rate cut very well as the US dollar is strong at present. It’s also a resounding statement of intent, that the ECB is not going to sit on its hands as the eurozone slides towards deflation. Here’s the full statement from the ECB, announcing its decision to cut interest rates. 4 September 2014 - Monetary policy decisions At today’s meeting the Governing Council of the ECB took the following monetary policy decisions: The interest rate on the main refinancing operations of the Eurosystem will be decreased by 10 basis points to 0.05%, starting from the operation to be settled on 10 September 2014. The interest rate on the marginal lending facility will be decreased by 10 basis points to 0.30%, with effect from 10 September 2014. The interest rate on the deposit facility will be decreased by 10 basis points to -0.20%, with effect from 10 September 2014. The President of the ECB will comment on the considerations underlying these decisions at a press conference starting at 2.30 p.m. CET today.  So, no mention of new measures such as the €500bn ABS programme which was rumoured to be under consideration (new readers should click here). But Mario Draghi may be saving new measures back for his press conference in 30 minutes.... The euro has tumbled by over a cent against the US dollar to a new one-year low, as traders react to the unexpected cut in interest rates. It has hit €1.3048, a fall of 0.8%, to the lowest rate in over a year. Breaking: The European Central Bank has cut interest rates across the eurozone. Weak growth and falling inflation has prompted the ECB to ease policy again, at today’s meeting in Brussels. The headline interest rate has been slashed to just 0.05%, from 0.15% before. And banks are being hit with more costly negative interest rates -- they’ll be charged 0.2% to leave cash at the ECB. The news that the ECB is considering a €500bn programme to buy up asset-backed securities and covered bonds (see here) has pushed the euro down a little (-0.15% at $1.3132). The potential size of the three-year programme has surprised some economists, who point out that the total ABS market isn’t much larger, even if you include packages of home loans (residential mortgage-backed securities). However, such a plan would be designed to stimulate the currently-moribund ABS market, not simply mop up what’s available today. Turn to flows-vs-stocks in your economics textbooks.... Traders, analysts and economists across the City, and beyond, are scrambling for lunch before the European Central Bank announces its decision on monetary policy in around 15 minutes. So here’s a quick recap. The ECB’s governing council is reported to be considering a €500bn programme to encourage eurozone banks to make new loans, securitise them, and sell them on. Details could come at 1.30pm BST in Mario Draghi’s press conference. Most economists expect the ECB will resist a full-blown quantitative easing programme today... although it could come early next year. Eurogroup president Jeroen Dijsselbloem has warned that the eurozone recovery remains very fragile and uneven. Dijsselbloem also told MEPs that he believes the region will avoid deflation, and that governments must implement structural reforms. The Bank of England has left interest rates unchanged. The UK interest rate decision has been welcomed by the British Chambers of Commerce, who are worried that the Bank of England will start hiking too soon. BCC chief economist David Kern said: The UK recovery is on track but there are still challenges up ahead. The eurozone, our largest export market, is stagnant and official figures show that manufacturing activity is at its lowest level since June last year. We must act with caution and ensure the recovery is not put at risk with unnecessary interest rate increases.” The looming Scottish independence vote probably encouraged the Bank of England to sit tight at this week’s meeting. Any excuse to mention Clement Attlee: To no-one’s surprise, the Bank of England has left UK interest rates unchanged at 0.5%, and also maintained its QE programme at £375bn. We now have to wait two weeks for the minutes of today’s meeting, to find how many MPC members wanted a rate rise (it split 7-2 last month). It could be announced today, unless there is opposition from members of the council. The ECB has declined to comment. Here’s Reuters’ first take: Plans to launch an asset-backed securities (ABS) and covered bond purchase programme worth up to 500 billion euros are on the table at Thursday’s European Central Bank policy meeting, people familiar with the discussions say. The programme would have a duration of three years and comprise both ABS and covered bond purchases. The ECB could begin buying the assets this year, the people familiar with the discussions told Reuters.The ECB declined to comment. It’s not a shock that the ECB is considering an ABS programme, of course. But the size of the programme is new. And if it doesn’t happen now, we’ll know that there are divisions over the plan. Also, it’s pretty rare to get a central bank leak during the meeting... In the UK, car sales have risen for the 30th month running, a record, as consumers continue to splash out on new models. A sign that consumer confidence remains solid, and is underpinning the recovery (there’ s also speculation that PPI mis-selling payouts has been pushing demand) More here: UK drivers splash out on new cars as record run of sales continues Very droll, sir.... For new readers, ABS = asset backed securities. Mario Draghi may pre-announce details of an ABS programme to encourage banks to package together, or securitise, loans into a new debt instrument to sell to the ECB. Securitisation, of course, was one cause of the 2008 financial crisis, after banks bundling some pretty dubious home loans together and selling them on. Jeroen Dijsselbloem went on to tell MEPs that he doesn’t believe the eurozone will slip into deflation, despite the CPI measure of inflation hitting a five-year low of just 0.3%. He said: “I don’t actually see deflationary risks , but I see a risk of a long term of a very low inflation which has to be broken through.” The eurozone recovery is very uneven and fragile, but the European Central Bank should resist launching new measures today. That’s the message from the head of the eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers, Jeroen Dijsselbloem. Testifying in Brussels this morning, Dijsselbloem said that governments must implement structural reforms, rather than simply rely on easy monetary policy. He also argued that the European Central Bank shouldn’t launch a quantitative easing programme now, as we don’t know whether its existing measures will work. Dijsselbloem, who is also the Dutch finance minister, told the European Parliament’s economic and monetary committee that: Recent economic data confirm that the recovery in the euro zone remains very fragile and uneven. He was made interim CEO in March after Euan Sutherland dramatically quit, saying the group was ungovernable... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the economy, the eurozone and business. With growth stalling, prices heading towards deflation, and geopolitical risks on the rise, this is a tricky time to be a central banker. And today, Mario Draghi and the rest of the European Central Bank’s governing council must decide whether to take fresh action to aid the eurozone. They’re meeting in Frankfurt this morning to set monetary policy across the region. We get their decision at 12.45pm BST, followed by the big event of the day (if not the week), Draghi’s press conference at 1.30pm BST. It’s the first ECB meeting since Draghi dramatically pledged to use “all available instruments needed to ensure price stability”. The latest slump in inflation, to just 0.3% in August, means this could be the day when the ECB takes the historic decision to launch a huge quantitative easing programme (buying government bonds on a major scale). But it almost certainly won’t be. QE may be coming soon, but it’s more likely that today Draghi will talk up another weapon in the ECB’s armoury. Many economists believe he’ll pre-announce a plan to buy asset-backed securities (ABSs) from eurozone banks. An ABS programme could encourage banks to agree loans with businesses, so the debt can be packaged up into a new security and sold to the ECB. That might help. But Julian Jessop of Capital Economics reckons the ECB must launch QE eventually... It has also been our long-held view that the ECB will eventually be forced to adopt full-blown quantitative easing (QE), involving large-scale outright purchases of government bonds. And the latest activity and price data, including evidence on inflation expectations, have surely brought the timing of that announcement forward. With interest rates so low, a further cut in borrowing costs is unlikely, but not impossible. The ECB will also update its economic forecasts; its staff are likely to have taken the red pen to June’s projections, given the weak inflation and GDP figures since. It’s also Bank of England decision day. We’re not expecting a change in interest rates, even though the monetary policy committee split 7-2 last month. But with the services sector growing strongly last month, and construction firms struggling to find skilled staff, there’s lots for the BoE to ponder. Their decision comes at noon BST. The stock markets look calm this morning, after the FTSE 100 hit a new 14 year high yesterday. Also coming up.... 9am: The UK car registrations figures, for August. 1.15pm BST: The monthly measure of US private sector employment, which will give clues to tomorrow’s non-farm payroll.

webTitle: The ECB will need to act swiftly to avoid quantitative easing | Larry Elliott

fields.bodyText: Mario Draghi chose his moment well. The financial markets were expecting the meeting of the governing council of the European Central Bank to be a non-event. As it happened, it was anything but the expected big yawn. The first surprise was that the ECB again cut interest rates, despite Draghi having said earlier in the summer that they were already at rock bottom levels. The second shocker was the announcement that the bank would start to purchase asset-backed securities as a way of getting money into the banking system. The reason for the action is simple: growth in the eurozone looks a lot weaker than it did earlier in the year. A fresh recession could drive the single currency zone into outright deflation, so the ECB is doing its level best to import some inflation by driving down the value of the euro. By picking a moment when the dollar was already riding high on the foreign exchanges, Draghi managed to push the single currency down by two cents yesterday. The plan, clearly, is to get ahead of the curve and so avoid the need for full-blown quantitative easing (QE), something Germany and its allies oppose. But if buying asset-backed securities doesn't work, QE will be the one remaining shot in the locker. In truth, it all looks too little, too late. European banks do not seem to be short of cash; rather, it is that they are unwilling to lend and that animal spirits among businesses are so low. Keynes, who called this pushing on a piece of string, would be advocating cuts in taxes or higher public spending as a way of generating growth. That is, indeed, the way forward. Germany could avoid the need for QE by running down its budget surplus, thus boosting consumption and helping other eurozone countries. If the ECB does deploy QE, it should bypass banks more inclined to hoard than lend. Any new money should go directly to consumers or be used for capital investment projects.

webTitle: Co-operative Group toasts success of world-beating champagne

fields.bodyText: After months of bad news, champagne corks have been popping for more than one reason at the Co-operative Group. Richard Pennycook was no doubt toasting his appointment as the mutual's permanent chief executive and a return to profitability with a glass of Co-operative Les Pionniers vintage champagne after the fizz was awarded three of the industry's world champion titles. Named after the Rochdale Pioneers who founded the Co-op from the Lancashire mills in 1844, the supermarket scooped the champagne and sparkling wine world championship awards for greatest value champagne, best vintage Brut blend and best supermarket vintage champagne – beating more upmarket rivals including Waitrose and Moët. Judges said the wins by the wine, developed alongside a longstanding partnership with the Piper and Charles Heidsieck champagne house, led by feted wine maker Regis Camus, was "possibly the most amazing result of the entire competition". "Unlike so many own-label champagnes, its strength lies in its superior construction with components from Le Mesnil-sur-Oger adding class, longevity, and minerality to the rest of this cuvée's chardonnay, which comes from the southern part of the Sézanne region," they said.

webTitle: French rogue trader Jérôme Kerviel freed

fields.standfirst: Former trader who lost Sociéte Générale £4.9bn released by appeal court after serving 110 days of five-year prison sentence
fields.body:
In the end it worked out at just one day in prison for every €50m (£40m) lost by the French rogue trader Jérôme Kerviel, who was freed by an appeal court on Thursday.

Kerviel was convicted in 2010 and sentenced to five years in jail – two suspended – and ordered to repay almost €5bn he had lost the French bank Sociéte Générale in unauthorised deals .

After numerous appeals and legal wrangling, he was released by the Paris appeal court on Thursday after 110 days in prison. The judge rejected a demand by French prosecutors that Kerviel remain in jail but ordered him to wear an electronic tag.

The former trader, who carried out one of the biggest trading frauds in history, had been told in March that he would not have to repay the bank.

The 37-year-old had managed to stay the 2010 sentence through the lengthy appeal process but was jailed in May after returning from Italy where he met Pope Francis. Kerviel was arrested after crossing the border into France while on a much-publicised two-month pilgrimage from Rome to Paris to draw attention to the "tyranny" of financial markets.

At the beginning of August, he was given a conditional release from prison, but was denied his freedom after a successful appeal against the decision by the prosecutor's office. That appeal was overturned on Thursday.

Kerviel has portrayed himself as a victim of a financial system that ignored his deals while they made money, but hung him out to dry when he accumulated losses.

At one point, he ran up about €38bn in unauthorised trades, which when discovered had to be carefully unwound. Sociéte Générale says the process cost it €4.9bn, the biggest banking loss of its kind in history. The bank almost collapsed as a result of the losses discovered in 2008.

In May 2010, Kerviel, who has never denied making unauthorised trades, wrote a book L'engrenage: mémoires d'un trader (Downward Spiral: Memoirs of a Trader) alleging his superiors knew of his trading activities. He is not believed to have profited personally.

His case has become something of a cause célèbre in France where he is seen by many, including leading figures in the Roman Catholic church, as a scapegoat for the shortcomings of the global banking system and capitalism.

But the French finance minister, Michel Sapin, earlier went on television to describe Kerviel as a "crook" who should serve his sentence.

The Co-op came close to collapse last year and governance reform was seen as vital to stabilise the business and allay the concerns of banks it owed £1.4bn. Ursula Lidbetter, who chairs the group, said the board could not have interviewed candidates for the job before the governance vote was passed and that it had decided to act quickly. "It would have been very time consuming and costly to have gone out with a formal [recruitment] process. Richard has the experience and the right attributes to run a cooperative society." Pennycook had said he was not interested in being chief executive permanently. But on Thursday he said governance reforms, including installing business people as directors to replace largely amateur Co-op members, had changed his mind. He also claimed to have been won over to the idea of co-operative values. Pennycook said: "For me, the defining moment was the governance change at the weekend. I had a very strong view that this is a national institution and a unique organisation which should be important in the nation. "After many years in the plc world I was very excited by the possibility of operating in a cooperative environment where that purpose really is unique." Lord Myners, whose report the changes were based on, told the Guardian on Sunday that the Co-op needed to recruit strong executives from outside the group for the reforms to work effectively. Pennycook argued he and his team matched up to Myners' standards. "If you look at the whole executive team we are strong executives largely from outside the group. In that respect, what we have on the executive team is very much what you're describing." Pennycook joined the Co-op as chief operating officer in June 2013 from the supermarket group Morrisons where he was finance director. He was part of a new management team headed by Sutherland, a former B&Q head. Sutherland was unpopular with members who believed he wanted to turn the group, founded by the Rochdale pioneers 170 years ago and owned by its 8m customers, into a plc. When Sutherland quit in March he branded the Co-op "ungovernable". Since taking over, Pennycook has agreed to sell the Co-op's farms for £249m and pharmacy business for £620m. On Tuesday, the group announced it was selling its Sunwin security services business to the cash machine operator Cardtronics for up to £41.5m. He warned that after cutting "a number of thousands" of jobs there would be more job reductions in store for the group's 87,000 employees but that cuts would be handled sensitively. About half the money from selling the three businesses will be used to pay off borrowing, leaving the group with about £1bn of debt, which Pennycook said was manageable. The rest will be used to revamp stores, cut prices and launch new products under the new strapline "championing a better way of doing business for you and your communities". webTitle: UK drivers splash out on new cars as record run of sales continues

fields.bodyText: British consumers continued to splash out on new cars in August, extending the record unbroken run of sales growth to two-and-a-half years. New car sales were 9.5% higher than August 2013, with 72,163 vehicles registered, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). It marked the 30th consecutive month of growth in new car sales, the longest since records began in 1959, with consumers spurred on by cheap finance deals and a desire for more fuel-efficient models. August is typically one of the quietest months for new car sales, falling just before the September plate change and accounting for abound 3% of annual sales. September usually accounts for about 18% of new car sales each year. Economists said growth in August sent a positive signal about the industry's short-term health but warned that weak wage growth and the prospect of rising interest rates may start to weigh on the car market. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The economic fundamentals still look largely positive for the motor industry which will hopefully fuel ongoing healthy car sales – although the growth rate is highly likely to ease back given double-digit growth both in 2013 and over the first eight months of 2014. "One concern for car manufacturers is that extended low earnings growth could become a constraint for private car sales while some consumers will also be worried by the prospect that interest rates will start to rise before long." The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in the early months of next year. Rates have been on hold at an all-time low of 0.5% since March 2009 in response to the financial crisis. Wage growth has lagged behind inflation for much of the past six years, with persistent falls in real pay. Such pressure on household finances has not been reflected in the new car sales data. A total of 1.53m new cars have been registered in 2014 so far, 10.1% more than at the same stage last year. Last month, the SMMT raised its 2014 forecast for new car sales for the second time this year. It now expects sales to jump 8.1% to 2.45m, underpinned by cheap finance deals and a better-than-expected economic backdrop, with unemployment falling faster and consumer confidence at higher levels. The Ford Fiesta was the bestseller in August, followed by the Ford Focus and Vauxhall Corsa, mirroring the top three best sellers in the year to date. Mike Hawes, SMMT chief executive, said buyers were snapping up "enticing deals on a wealth of advanced new products". He added: "The UK's performance in the context of Europe is particularly impressive, with growth consistently ahead of the rest of the EU for the past two years. As the UK market starts to find its natural level, we expect to see the growth level off during coming months." David Raistrick, UK automotive leader at Deloitte, said there were other risks to the new UK car market, as well as rising borrowing costs. "Aside from a potential interest rate rise, the biggest challenge facing the automotive retail sector will be the impact of the increasing numbers of nearly new used vehicles returning to the market. "This could detrimentally affect residual values with the knock-on effect that the used-vehicle purchase becomes a more competitive proposition – bringing an element of balance back to the industry."
